summary: Returns the absolute value of a number.
name: abs

parameters.description: time unit - allowed options are: y, years, mo, months, w, weeks, d [default], days, h, hours, m, minutes, s, seconds
parameters.name: unit

return_type.description: modified time

examples.raw_liquid: {{ 'now' | add_to_time: 1, 'w' }} # => returns current time plus one week
{{ 'now' | add_to_time: 3, 'mo' }} # => returns current time plus three months

parameters.description: object you want to format
parameters.name: argument_to_format

parameters.description: should look like: %[flags][width][.precision]type. For more examples and information see: https://ruby-doc.org/core-2.5.1/Kernel.html#method-i-sprintf
parameters.name: format

return_type.description: formatted string

examples.raw_liquid:
{{ 3 | advanced_format: '%.2f' }} => 3.00
In the example above flags is not present, width is not present (refers to the total final
length of the string), precision ".2" means 2 digits after the decimal point,
type "f" means floating point

description: Converts amount in given currency to fractional. For example, convert USD to cents.
name: amount_to_fractional

parameters.description: amount to be changed to fractional
parameters.name: amount

parameters.description: currency to be used
parameters.name: currency

return_type.description: Amount in fractional, for example cents for USD

examples.raw_liquid:
{%-  assign path = product.url -%}

{{ request.origin | append: path }}

summary: Adds a given string to the end of a string.
name: append

parameters.description: array to which you add a new element
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: item you add to the array
parameters.name: item

return_type.description: array to which you add the item given as the second parameter

parameters.description: array to search in
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: String/Number compared to each item in the given array
parameters.name: query

return_type.description: checks if given array contains at least one of the queried string/number

examples.raw_liquid:
{% assign elements = 'foo,bar' | split: ',' %}
{{ elements | array_any: 'foo' }} => true

description: Removes blank elements from the array
name: array_compact

parameters.description: array with some blank values
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: optionally if you provide Hash as argument, you can remove elements which given key is blank
parameters.name: property

return_type.description: array from which blank values are removed

examples.raw_liquid:
{% parse_json empty_object %}{}{% endparse_json %}
{{ '1,' | split: ',' | array_add: empty_object | array_add: '2' | array_compact }} => 12

{% assign empty_array = ',' | split: ',' %}
{{ '1,' | split: ',' | array_add: empty_array | array_add: '2' | array_compact }} => 12

{% parse_json hash %}[{ "hello": null }, { "hello" => "world" }, { "hello" => "" }]{% endparse_json %}
{{ hash | array_compact: "hello" }} => [{ "hello":  "world" }]

parameters.description: array to process
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: value to remove
parameters.name: element

return_type.description: the initial array that has all occurences of "element" removed

examples.raw_liquid:
assign test = ['test', 'test2', 'test', 'test3']
assign arr = test | array_delete: 'test'
  => ['test2', 'test3']

parameters.description: array to process
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: array index to remove
parameters.name: index

return_type.description: the initial array that has the element at index removed

examples.raw_liquid:
assign test = ['test', 'test2']
assign arr = test | array_delete_at: 1
  => ['test']

parameters.description: array of objects to be processed

description: Transforms array in array of arrays, each subarray containing exactly N elements
name: array_in_groups_of

parameters.description: array to be split into groups
parameters.name: array

parameters.description: the size of each group the array is to be split into
parameters.name: number_of_elements

return_type.description:
the original array split into groups of the size
specified by the second parameter (an array of arrays)

examples.raw_liquid:
{% assign elements = '1,2,3,4' | split: ',' %}
{{ elements | array_in_groups_of: 3 }} => [[1, 2, 3], [4, null, null]]

description: Checks if array includes element

examples.raw_liquid:
{% assign elements = 'a,b,c,d' | split: ',' %}
{{ elements | array_include: 'c' }} => true

description: Finds index of an object in the array

parameters.description: array of objects to be processed

parameters.description: array of objects to be processed

examples.raw_liquid:
{% liquid
  assign array = '1,2,3,4' | split: ','
  assign other_array = '3,4,5,6' | split: ','
%}

{{ array | array_intersect: other_array }} => [3,4]

parameters.description: array to shrink

return_type.description: parameter; [1,2,3,4] limited to 2 elements gives [1,2]

examples.raw_liquid:
items => [{ id: 1, name: 'foo', label: 'Foo' }, { id: 2, name: 'bar', label: 'Bar' }]
{{ items | array_limit: 1 }} => [{ id: 1, name: 'foo', label: 'Foo' }]

parameters.description: array of keys to be extracted
parameters.name: attributes

return_type.description: array of arrays with values for given keys

examples.raw_liquid:
{{ items }} => [{ id: 1, name: 'foo', label: 'Foo' }, { id: 2, name: 'bar', label: 'Bar' }]
{{ items | array_map: 'id', 'name' }} => [[1, 'foo'], [2, 'bar']]

parameters.description: message to be authenticated

parameters.description:
defaults to SHA256. Supported algorithms are:
SHA, SHA1, SHA224, SHA256, SHA384, SHA512, MD4, MDC2, MD5, RIPEMD160, DSS1.
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: defaults to hex. Supported digest values are hex, none, base64

return_type.description:
Keyed-hash message authentication code (HMAC), that can

description:
> Note:
> The `concat` filter won't filter out duplicates. If you want to remove duplicates, then you need to use the
> [`uniq` filter](/docs/api/liquid/filters/uniq).
name: concat

description:
The `date` filter accepts the same parameters as Ruby's strftime method for formatting the date. For a list of shorthand
formats, refer to the [Ruby documentation](https://ruby-doc.org/core-3.1.1/Time.html#method-i-strftime) or
[strftime reference and sandbox](http://www.strfti.me/).

parameters.description: The desired date format.
parameters.name: format

examples.name: The current date
examples.description:
You can apply the `date` filter to the keywords `'now'` and `'today'` to output the current timestamp.

> Note:
> The timestamp will reflect the time that the Liquid was last rendered. Because of this, the timestamp might not be updated for every page view, depending on the context and caching.

examples.name: format
examples.description:
Specify a locale-aware date format. You can use the following formats:

- `abbreviated_date`
- `basic`
- `date`
- `date_at_time`
- `default`
- `on_date`
- `short` (deprecated)
- `long` (deprecated)

> Note:
> You can also [define custom formats](/docs/api/liquid/filters/date-setting-format-options-in-locale-files) in your theme's locale files.

examples.name: Setting format options in locale files

summary: Converts a timestamp into another date format.
name: date

parameters.description: time unit - allowed options are: y, years, mo, months, w, weeks, d [default], days, h, hours, m, minutes, s, seconds
parameters.name: unit

return_type.description: modified Date

description: Filter allowing to decrypt data encrypted with a specified algorithm. See encrypt filter for encryption.
name: decrypt

parameters.description: string payload to be decrypted - must be a Base64 encoded (RFC 4648) or HEX (if from_hex flag true) string
parameters.name: payload

parameters.description: algorithm you want to use for encryption
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: a key used for encryption. Key must match the algorithm requirments. For asymmetric algorithms there are public and private keys that need to passed in PEM format.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: - a Hash with additional options to control the decryption algorithm
parameters.name: options

return_type.description: String - decrypted string using the algorithm of your choice. Initialization Vector (iv) is expected to be present in the encrypted payload at the beginning.

examples.raw_liquid:
{{ some_payload | decrypt: 'aes-256-cbc', 'ThisPasswordIsReallyHardToGuessA' }} => decrypted string from payload
{{ "43553EEDD9BFE36D10F99E931245CF8826903C00D235DFD300B3CC40BD263A621FC2FB9F5C3743F75D399A912AFABF92371927C6D190E0EFF19EAE9802320391FED79D92009796403EC6B426E901AB981CE53A43557C295F3D6FC9678EE0557F" | decrypt: 'aes-128-ecb', '4FCD5FAE2AC493C0F8CE8E1E6105D194', true, true, true  }} => iframe=true;customer.firstName=John;customer.lastName=Smith;header.accountNumber=6759370;header.authToken1=12345;header.paymentTypeCode=UTILITY;header.amount=123.45

parameters.description: object to be duplicated
parameters.name: object

return_type.description: returns a copy of the object parameter

parameters.description: Whether to use false values instead of the default.
parameters.name: allow_false

examples.name: allow_false
examples.description: By default, the  `default` filter's value will be used in place of `false` values. You can use the `allow_false` parameter to allow variables to return `false` instead of the default value.
examples.raw_liquid:
{%- assign display_price = false -%}

{{ display_price | default: true, allow_false: true }}

summary:
Sets a default value for any variable whose value is one of the following:

- [`empty`](/docs/api/liquid/basics#empty)
- [`false`](/docs/api/liquid/basics#truthy-and-falsy)
- [`nil`](/docs/api/liquid/basics#nil)
name: default

parameters.description: message that you want to obtain a cryptographic hash for
parameters.name: object

parameters.description: the hash algorithm to use. Choose from: 'md5', 'sha1', 'sha256', 'sha384', 'sha512'. Default is sha1.
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: defaults to hex. Supported digest values are hex, none, base64
parameters.name: digest

return_type.description: hexadecimal hash value obtained by applying the selected algorithm to the message

summary: Divides a number by a given number. The `divided_by` filter produces a result of the same type as the divisor. This means if you divide by an integer, the result will be an integer, and if you divide by a float, the result will be a float.
name: divided_by

summary: Converts a string to all lowercase characters.
name: downcase

parameters.description: url to a remote file
parameters.name: url

parameters.description: max file size of the file, default 1 megabyte. Can't exceed 50 megabytes.
parameters.name: max_size

return_type.description: Body of the remote file

examples.raw_liquid:
{{ 'http://www.example.com/my_file.txt' | download_file }} => "Content of a file"
{% assign data = 'https://example.com/data.json' | download_file | parse_json %}

description: The filter returns a string with the encoding changed to the one specified by the 'destination_encoding' parameter. The filter changes the string itself (its representation in memory) by first determining which graphical characters the underlying bytes in the string represent in the 'source_encoding', and then changing the bytes to encode the same graphical characters in 'destination_encoding'.
name: encode

parameters.description: input string that we want to reencode
parameters.name: text

parameters.description: the encoding of the source string text
parameters.name: source_encoding

parameters.description: the encoding we want the source string text converted to
parameters.name: destination_encoding

parameters.description: if set to 'replace', invalid byte sequences for the source_encoding will be replaced with the replace parameter
parameters.name: invalid

parameters.description: if set to 'replace', characters which do not exist in the destination encoding will be replaced by the 'replace' parameter
parameters.name: undefined

parameters.description: used together with the invalid and undefined parameters
parameters.name: replace

return_type.description: input string with encoding modified from source_encoding to destination_encoding

description: The filter returns the encoding of the string parameter (i.e. how the underlying bytes in the string are interpreted to determine which graphical characters they encode).
name: encoding

parameters.description: input string whose encoding we want to find
parameters.name: text

return_type.description: encoding of the string text

description: Filter allowing to encrypt data with specified algorithm. See decrypt filter for decryption
name: encrypt

parameters.description: string payload to be encrypted
parameters.name: payload

parameters.description: algorithm you want to use for encryption
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: a key used for encryption. Key must match the algorithm requirments. For asymmetric algorithms there are public and private keys that need to passed in PEM format.
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: - initialization vector, if not provided we will automatically generate one
parameters.name: iv

parameters.description: - a Hash with additional options to control the encrypt algorithm
parameters.name: options

return_type.description: Base64 encoded (RFC 4648) (or HEX if return_hex is true) encrypted string using the algorithm of your choice. Initialization Vector (iv) will be appended

description: Check if string ends with given substring(s)
name: end_with

parameters.description: string to check ends with any of the provided suffixes
parameters.name: string

parameters.description: suffix to check

return_type.description: true if string ends with a suffixes

examples.raw_liquid:
{% assign suffixes = ['array', 'example'] | parse_json %}
{{ 'my_example' | end_with: suffixes } => true

summary: Escapes special characters in HTML, such as `<>`, `'`, and `&`, and converts characters into escape sequences. The filter doesn't effect characters within the string that donâ€™t have a corresponding escape sequence.".

return_type.description: escaped text

hash with added key

examples.raw_liquid:
{% liquid
  assign accountants = "Angela,Kevin,Oscar" | split: ","
  assign management = "David,Jan,Michael" | split: ","
  assign company = '{}' | parse_json
  assign company = company | hash_add_key: "name", "Dunder Mifflin"
  assign company = company | hash_add_key: "accountants", accountants
  assign company = company | hash_add_key: "management", management
%}
{{ company }} => {"name"=>"Dunder Mifflin", "accountants"=>["Angela", "Kevin", "Oscar"], "management"=>["David", "Jan", "Michael"]}

return_type.description: value which was assigned to a deleted key. If the key did not exist in the first place, null is returned.

description: Generates a list of additions (+), deletions (-) and changes (~) from given two ojects.
name: hash_diff

return_type.description: array containg the difference between two hashes

Extracted nested value specified by the sequence of keys by calling dig at each step,
returning null if any intermediate step is null.

parameters.description: key to be fetched from hash branch
parameters.name: key

parameters.description: input hash
parameters.name: hash

examples.raw_liquid:
{% liquid
  assign data = null | hash_merge: foo: 'fooval', bar: 'barval'
%}

{{ data | hash_keys }} => ["foo", "bar"]

return_type.description:
new hash containing the contents of hash1 and the contents of hash2.
On duplicated keys we keep value from hash2

%}

{{ data | hash_values }} => ["fooval", "barval"]

parameters.description: params sent to the server

parameters.description: set raw_text to true to stop it from unescaping HTML entities
parameters.name: options

examples.raw_liquid: {{ '<script>alert("Hello")</script>' }} => <script>alert("Hello")</script> - this will just print text in the source code of the page
{{ '<script>alert("Hello")</script>' | html_safe }} => <script>alert("Hello")</script> - this script will be evaluated when a user enters the page

description: Temporary token is valid for desired number of hours (by default 48), which you can use to authorize the user in third party application. To do it, include it in a header with name UserTemporaryToken. Token will be invalidated on password change.
name: is_token_valid

parameters.description: encrypted token generated via the temporary_token GraphQL property
parameters.name: token

parameters.description: id of the user who generated the token
parameters.name: user_id

return_type.description: returns true if the token has not expired and was generated for the given user, false otherwise

examples.name: Custom separator
examples.description: You can specify a custom separator for the joined items.

summary: Combines all of the items in an array into a single string, separated by a space.
name: join

parameters.description: object you want a JSON representation of
parameters.name: object

return_type.description: JSON formatted string containing a representation of object.

parameters.description: JSON body string that will be encypted
parameters.name: json

parameters.description: Public key
parameters.name: key

parameters.description:
- Key Management Algorithm used to encrypt or determine the value of the Content Encryption Key.
Valid options:
  Single Asymmetric Public/Private Key Pair
      RSA1_5
      RSA-OAEP
      RSA-OAEP-256
  Two Asymmetric Public/Private Key Pairs with Key Agreement
      ECDH-ES
      ECDH-ES+A128KW
      ECDH-ES+A192KW
      ECDH-ES+A256KW
  Symmetric Password Based Key Derivation
      PBES2-HS256+A128KW
      PBES2-HS384+A192KW
      PBES2-HS512+A256KW
  Symmetric Key Wrap
      A128GCMKW
      A192GCMKW
      A256GCMKW
      A128KW
      A192KW
      A256KW
  Symmetric Direct Key (known to both sides)
      dir
parameters.name: alg

parameters.description:
- Encryption Algorithm used to perform authenticated encryption on the plain text using the Content Encryption Key.
Valid options:
  A128CBC-HS256
  A192CBC-HS384
  A256CBC-HS512
  A128GCM
  A192GCM
  A256GCM
parameters.name: enc

parameters.description: encoded JWT token you want to decode
parameters.name: encoded_token

parameters.description: the algorithm that was used to encode the token
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: either a shared secret or a PUBLIC key for RSA
parameters.name: secret

parameters.description: default true, for testing and debugging can remove verifying the signature
parameters.name: verify_signature

parameters.description:
JWK is a structure representing a cryptographic key. Currently only supports RSA public keys.
Valid options:
  none - unsigned token
  HS256 - SHA-256 hash algorithm
  HS384 - SHA-384 hash algorithm
  HS512 - SHA-512 hash algorithm
  RS256 - RSA using SHA-256 hash algorithm
  RS384 - RSA using SHA-384 hash algorithm
  RS512 - RSA using SHA-512 hash algorithm
parameters.name: jwks

return_type.description: result of decoding JWT token

parameters.description: payload or message you want to encrypt
parameters.name: payload

parameters.description: algorithm you want to use for encryption
parameters.name: algorithm

parameters.description: either a shared secret or a private key for RSA
parameters.name: secret

parameters.description: optional hash of custom headers to be added to default { "typ": "JWT", "alg": "[algorithm]" }
parameters.name: header_fields

return_type.description: JWT token encrypted using the algorithm of your choice

examples.name: Dot notation
examples.description: You can use the `last` filter with dot notation when you need to use it inside a tag or object output.

summary: Returns the last item in an array.
name: last

the format to be used for formatting the time; default is 'long'; other values can be used:
they are taken from translations, keys are of the form 'time.formats.#!{format_name}'

parameters.description: regexp to use for matching
parameters.name: regexp

parameters.description: can contain 'ixm'; i - ignore case, x - extended, m #   - multiline (e.g. 'ix', 'm', 'mi' etc.)
parameters.name: options

examples.raw_liquid:
To retrieve the URL from a meta tag see the example below:

{% liquid
  assign text = '<html><head><meta property="og:image" content="http://somehost.com/someimage.jpg" /></head><body>content</body></html>' | html_safe %}
  assign matches = text | regex_matches: '<meta\s+property="og:image"\s+content="([^"]+)"'
  if matches.size > 0
    assign image_path = matches[0][0]
    echo image_path
  endif
%}

summary: Removes any instance of a substring inside a string.
name: remove

examples.raw_liquid: {{ "I hate it when I accidentally spill my duplication potion accidentally!" | remove_first: ' accidentally' }}

summary: Removes the first instance of a substring inside a string.
name: remove_first

summary: Replaces any instance of a substring inside a string with a given string.
name: replace

summary: Replaces the first instance of a substring inside a string with a given string.
name: replace_first

parameters.description: regexp to use for matching
parameters.name: regexp

parameters.description:
replacement text, or hash; if hash, keys in
the hash must be matched texts and values their replacements
parameters.name: replacement

parameters.description: can contain 'ixm'; i - ignore case, x - extended, m #   - multiline (e.g. 'ix', 'm', 'mi' etc.)
parameters.name: options

parameters.description: whether all occurrences should be replaced or just the first
parameters.name: global

return_type.description: string with regexp pattern replaced by replacement text

examples.raw_liquid:
Global set to false:
{{ "fooooo fooo" | replace_regex: 'o+', 'o', '', false }} => "fo fooo"

Hash replacement:
{% liquid
  assign hash = '{}' | parse_json
  assign hash = hash | hash_add_key: 'ooooo', 'bbbbb'
  assign hash = hash | hash_add_key: 'ooo', 'ccc'
  %}
{{ "fooooo fooo" | replace_regex: 'o+', hash }} => "fbbbbb fccc"

Using options, ignore case:
{{ "FOOOOO" | replace_regex: 'o+', 'a', 'i' }} => "Fa"
{{ "FOOOOO" | replace_regex: 'o+', 'a' }} => "FOOOOO"
Using options, extended mode (insert spaces, newlines, and comments in the pattern to make it more readable):
{{ "FOOOOO" | replace_regex: 'o+ #comment', 'a', 'ix' }} => "Fa"
Using options, multiline (. matches newline):
{% capture newLine %}
{% endcapture %}
{{ "abc" | append: newLine | append: "def" | append: newLine | append: "ghi" | replace_regex: '.+', 'a', 'im' }} => "a"

examples.name: Reversing strings
examples.description: You can't use the `reverse` filter on strings directly. However, you can use the [`split` filter](/docs/api/liquid/filters/split) to create an array of characters in the string, reverse that array, and then use the [`join` filter](/docs/api/liquid/filters/join) to combine them again.

The size of a string is the number of characters that the string includes. The size of an array is the number of items
in the array.

By default, the substring has a length of one character, and the array series has one array item. However, you can
provide a second parameter to specify the number of characters or array items.

parameters.description: array you would like to convert to CSV
parameters.name: input

parameters.description: csv options
parameters.name: options

return_type.description:
String containing CSV.
If one of the array element contains separator, this element will automatically be wrapped in double quotes.

examples.raw_liquid:
{% liquid
  assign arr = '' | split: ','
  assign headers = 'id,header1,header2' | split: ','
  assign row1 = '1,example,value' | split: ','
  assign row2 = '2,another,val2' | split: ','
  assign arr = arr | array_add: headers | array_add: row1 | array_add: row2
%}
{{ arr | to_csv }} => "id","header1","header2"\n1,"example","value"\n2,"another","val2"

description:
If the specified number of characters is less than the length of the string, then an ellipsis (`...`) is appended to
the truncated string. The ellipsis is included in the character count of the truncated string.

examples.name: Specify a custom ellipsis
examples.description: You can provide a second parameter to specify a custom ellipsis. If you don't want an ellipsis, then you can supply an empty string.

summary: Truncates a string down to a given number of characters.
name: truncate

description:
If the specified number of words is less than the number of words in the string, then an ellipsis (`...`) is appended to
the truncated string.

> Caution:
> HTML tags are treated as words, so you should strip any HTML from truncated content. If you don't strip HTML, then
> closing HTML tags can be removed, which can result in unexpected behavior.

examples.name: Specify a custom ellipsis
examples.description: You can provide a second parameter to specify a custom ellipsis. If you don't want an ellipsis, then you can supply an empty string.
examples.raw_liquid:
{{ article.content | strip_html | truncatewords: 15, '--' }}

{{ article.content | strip_html | truncatewords: 15, '' }}

summary: Truncates a string down to a given number of words.
name: truncatewords

name: url_encode

  => "foo=bar&zoo[0][xoo]=555&zoo[1][xoo]=999",
